from a completely different animal known

like a jumping italian horse you

meat would you i really hope not tigers
are expensive carbonara is typically

since that's not what we're making don't

music really ruins this dish we'll just

thumb trick you can also do the back and
forth and whoops maybe no fourth then
make the traditional italian egg white
on toast as an appetizer
this is pecorino romano which you would

are not it gets its name because the

easily you can take a drill put in a
nice big fat screw then you just
okay so
all right if i just maybe okay let's try
no
see in my mind when i thought of this
none of the physics of how objects work
would be an issue if you're italian you
don't need to innovate in this
department because you simply harness
the power of your hand gesture muscles
which makes this a breeze so grate that
into the egg yolk and wang jangle until
you've got cadbury cream egg filling
then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper
and we're good to go and by go i mean
stay because we're not done yet the
original carbonara was made with
hand-crafted artisan spaghetti from the
veneto region each spaghetti crafts
person had their signature style sadly
these days you can only find straight
parallel lined spaghetti and you know it
just really angers me that the craft has
been left to die like nobody cares now
let's just fix that breaking spaghetti
in half is a crime in italy and can land
you in prison for up to nine months it
sounds like an overreaction at first but
the crack sends a shock wave through the
noodle rendering it completely inedible
i mean look here's uncracked spaghetti
and cracked spaghetti if i didn't tell
you that was spaghetti you wouldn't have
even recognized it now we'll salt this
angry water then throw in 156 pieces of
spaghetti keep wang jangling that for
the first bit to keep the spag from
getting clingy by the way spaghetti gets
its name because you put it in the spa
to cook it now our bacon is cooked we're
turning the burner off waiting for this
to cool at least until there's no sizzle
left in a bit longer so we don't
overcook the egg based sauce now i'm
gonna put in a bit of pasta water into
our sauce ingredients to get that cheese
a head start on the melting noodles go
straight from the water into the bacon
pan for a wangjangulation since noodles
are made of wheat this is essentially a
bacon sandwich but if you do strain the
spaghetti make sure to set aside some
pasta water and if you get the kind of
spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs just
pull those out and set them aside then
the sauce can go in and the egg will
cook just enough from the noodle heat
although you can put your pan on low to
thicken it as well because here comes
more pasta water making this nice and
creamy the reason we add pasta water is
so that if you get thirsty while you eat
it you don't have to stop and have a
drink here i'm trying to do that fancy
twist thing but it's not the right tool
and i don't know what i'm doing we'll
finish with some pepper pepper pepper
and some more pecorino or parmesan and
here we don't have carbonara if you want
to really see not carbonara here's an
earlier attempt where i used whole egg
too much heat and for some reason this
came out way worse than my first attempt
with whole egg which came out great so
are the whims of the food gods if this
was carbonara you'd have to be careful
because the carbonistic properties are
so fragile that if you put in a single
pea it would no longer be carbonara it's
a mysterious chemical reaction that only
italian scientists understand

i've added peace to a dish that is

hang my head as i eat this
shame

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The video humorously demonstrates how to make a dish similar to spaghetti carbonara, while emphasizing that it is not traditional carbonara.
meta_summary.procedure: The process involves chopping and cooking bacon, preparing a sauce with egg yolks and pecorino romano, cooking spaghetti, and combining these with pasta water to create a creamy sauce. The video uses humor to highlight deviations from traditional carbonara preparation, such as using bacon instead of guanciale, and omitting traditional steps for comedic effect.
meta_summary.outcome: The result is a dish that resembles spaghetti carbonara in taste and appearance but is intentionally not traditional carbonara, as emphasized by the humorous narrative throughout the video.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Black Peppercorns
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Chop and cook bacon to use as a substitute for guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.context: The goal is to create a dish similar to spaghetti carbonara, using bacon instead of guanciale as a humorous deviation from tradition.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Bacon, knife, frying pan, stove
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Chop the bacon into small pieces. 2. Heat a frying pan on the stove. 3. Add the bacon pieces to the pan and cook until crispy.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Bacon is used instead of guanciale to create a similar flavor profile while humorously deviating from traditional carbonara ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Cook the bacon until it's crispy to ensure a nice texture in the final dish.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Crispy bacon pieces ready to be combined with other ingredients to mimic carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Grate pecorino cheese and prepare the egg yolk mixture.
subgoal_summaries.context: The dish involves preparing a sauce with egg yolks and pecorino romano cheese, which is part of the humorous take on making a carbonara-like dish.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Egg yolks, pecorino romano cheese, pepper.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Hold the egg yolk with your thumb to separate it. 2. Grate pecorino romano cheese. 3. Mix the grated cheese with the egg yolks. 4. Add pepper to the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Mixing the cheese with egg yolks creates the base for a creamy sauce, a key component in the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use hand gestures to make grating easier, and ensure the mixture resembles a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A cheese and egg yolk mixture ready to be combined with other ingredients for the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Select and prepare the meat for the dish.
subgoal_summaries.context: The goal is to create a dish similar to spaghetti carbonara, using bacon instead of traditional guanciale as part of a humorous deviation from the traditional recipe.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Bacon
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop up some bacon.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Bacon is used instead of guanciale to humorously highlight the deviation from traditional carbonara, which would use guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.tips: The humor in the video emphasizes that bacon and guanciale come from different types of pigs, which is part of the comedic narrative.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Chopped bacon is ready to be cooked for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Organize Ingredients for Cooking
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Chop and cook bacon to use as a substitute for guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.context: The goal is to create a dish similar to spaghetti carbonara, using bacon instead of traditional guanciale for comedic effect.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Bacon, chopping board, knife, frying pan, spatula.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Chop the bacon into small pieces. 2. Heat a frying pan over medium heat. 3. Add the chopped bacon to the pan. 4. Cook until the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Bacon is used instead of guanciale to highlight the humorous deviation from traditional carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is crispy to mimic the texture of guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Crispy bacon pieces are ready to be used in the pasta dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the Pasta
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.context: The video humorously emphasizes the differences from traditional carbonara, using modern spaghetti instead of artisan varieties.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghetti, salted boiling water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Salt the boiling water. 2. Add 156 pieces of spaghetti to the water. 3. Stir for the first few minutes to prevent sticking.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Stirring prevents the spaghetti from sticking together during cooking.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Breaking spaghetti is humorously described as a serious offense in Italy, highlighting cultural cooking norms.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The spaghetti is cooked to the desired texture, ready to be combined with other ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Render the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Render the bacon and prepare it for combining with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The bacon has been chopped and is ready to be cooked as part of the dish preparation.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked bacon, stove, pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Cook the bacon until done. 2. Turn off the burner. 3. Wait for the bacon to cool until there's no sizzle left. 4. Let it cool a bit longer to prevent overcooking the egg-based sauce.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooling the bacon slightly prevents the egg-based sauce from overcooking when combined, ensuring a creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is not too hot when mixing with the sauce to avoid curdling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Bacon is rendered and cooled, ready to be combined with the sauce without overcooking it.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with the sauce and bacon.
subgoal_summaries.context: The cheese and egg yolk mixture is prepared, the spaghetti is cooked, and the bacon is rendered and cooled.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghetti, bacon, cheese and egg yolk mixture, pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Transfer cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the bacon pan. 2. Add the cheese and egg yolk mixture to the pan. 3. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. 4. Add pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The heat from the noodles will cook the egg just enough to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If straining spaghetti, set aside pasta water. Use low heat if needed to thicken the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Spaghetti is combined with bacon and sauce, achieving a creamy consistency with pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with the sauce and bacon.
subgoal_summaries.context: The cheese and egg yolk mixture is prepared, the spaghetti is cooked, and the bacon is rendered and cooled.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghetti, bacon, cheese and egg yolk mixture, pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Transfer cooked spaghetti directly from the water into the bacon pan. 2. Add the cheese and egg yolk mixture to the pan. 3. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. 4. Add pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The heat from the noodles will cook the egg just enough to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If straining spaghetti, set aside pasta water. Use low heat if needed to thicken the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Spaghetti is combined with bacon and sauce, achieving a creamy consistency with pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve and Garnish
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Serve and garnish the pasta dish.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta has been combined with the sauce and bacon, achieving a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Pepper, pecorino or parmesan cheese.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Attempt to twist the pasta for presentation. 2. Sprinkle pepper over the dish. 3. Add pecorino or parmesan cheese as a garnish.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The pepper and cheese enhance the flavor and presentation of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: The narrator humorously acknowledges a lack of expertise in twisting the pasta, suggesting the presentation step is not critical.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta dish is garnished with pepper and cheese, ready to be served.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The video demonstrates how to make traditional spaghetti carbonara without using cream, peas, or other non-traditional ingredients.
meta_summary.procedure: The video begins by explaining the traditional ingredients for carbonara, emphasizing the use of guanciale but opting for bacon due to availability. The bacon is cut thick and cooked in a pan to render the fat. Meanwhile, pasta water is boiled and seasoned lightly. Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses are grated and mixed with a combination of whole eggs and yolks, along with black pepper. The rendered bacon fat is partially drained, and the cooked spaghetti is mixed with the bacon and cheese-egg mixture, using the heat from the pasta to cook the eggs gently. The mixture is emulsified with pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency without scrambling the eggs. The dish is garnished with additional cheese and crispy bacon.
meta_summary.outcome: The final outcome is a creamy, rich spaghetti carbonara with a velvety sauce, topped with crispy bacon and additional cheese, achieving a traditional taste without non-traditional additives.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Black Peppercorns
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the bacon to render its fat.
subgoal_summaries.context: The bacon is cut thick and needs to be cooked to render its fat before combining with pasta and cheese-egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Thick-cut bacon, frying pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Place the thick-cut bacon in a frying pan. 2. Cook on medium heat until the fat is rendered and the bacon is crispy. 3. Partially drain the rendered fat, leaving some in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooking the bacon renders its fat, which is used to flavor the dish and helps in emulsifying the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Keep an eye on the bacon to prevent burning; you want it crispy but not overcooked.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Crispy bacon with rendered fat, ready to be combined with pasta and cheese-egg mixture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Grate cheese and prepare the egg mixture for carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: Water is boiling for the pasta, and the bacon is being cooked to render fat. Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses are needed for the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, cheese grater, box grater (optional), 3 whole eggs, 2 egg yolks, black pepper, pepper grinder, whisk.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Grate about 3 ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses using a cheese grater or the fine setting on a box grater. 2. Crack 3 whole eggs and 2 egg yolks into a bowl. 3. Whisk the eggs until combined. 4. Gradually whisk the grated cheeses into the egg mixture. 5. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it in. 6. Optionally, add about a quarter cup of boiling pasta water to the egg mixture to temper it.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Grating the cheese finely ensures it blends smoothly into the egg mixture, creating a creamy sauce. Mixing whole eggs and yolks balances richness. Adding pasta water tempers the eggs, preventing them from scrambling when mixed with hot pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano for authentic flavor. Adjust the amount of black pepper to your preference.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A smooth, well-mixed egg and cheese mixture ready to be combined with the pasta and bacon for the carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Select and prepare the meat for spaghetti carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The video aims to make traditional spaghetti carbonara, typically using guanciale, but opts for bacon due to its availability and to cater to an American audience.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Thick-cut bacon (or pancetta as an alternative), knife.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Take about a half pound of thick-cut bacon. 2. Slice the bacon into thick pieces, approximately three-quarters of an inch thick.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Bacon is used instead of guanciale to make the recipe more accessible for an American audience. Thick slices provide a substantial texture and contribute to the dish's flavor profile.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Thick-cut bacon is preferred for better texture, but pancetta can be used as an alternative.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Thickly sliced bacon is prepared, ready to be cooked and used in the carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Organize Ingredients for Cooking
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the bacon to render its fat.
subgoal_summaries.context: The bacon is cut thick and needs to be cooked to render its fat before combining with pasta and cheese-egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Thick-cut bacon, frying pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Place the thick-cut bacon in a frying pan. 2. Cook on medium heat until the fat is rendered and the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Rendering the fat is essential for creating the base of the sauce and adding flavor to the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Cook the bacon until crispy to enhance the texture and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The bacon is crispy, and the fat is rendered, ready to be combined with the pasta and sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the Pasta
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the pasta to al dente.
subgoal_summaries.context: The bacon is being rendered in a pan. Pasta water is boiled and seasoned lightly.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghetti, salted boiling water, pan with rendered bacon fat, paper towel.
subgoal_summaries.instructions:
1. Drop the spaghetti into the boiling water. 
2. Stir the pasta to prevent sticking.
3. Cook the pasta until al dente.
4. Check the bacon; turn down the heat if necessary.
5. Remove some bacon for garnish and drain on a paper towel.
6. Turn off the heat from the bacon pan and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooking the pasta to al dente ensures the right texture and flavor, which is crucial for the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid adding olive oil to the pasta water as it serves no purpose. Use inexpensive Italian pasta brands for good quality at a lower cost.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is cooked to al dente, and bacon is ready to be mixed with the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Render the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Render the bacon to extract fat and crisp it up.
subgoal_summaries.context: Thick-cut bacon has been sliced and is ready to be cooked.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Pan, olive oil (optional), sliced bacon, stove.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Turn the pan on to medium heat. 2. Add a tiny bit of olive oil to the pan. 3. Break the sliced bacon into the pan. 4. Slowly render the fat from the bacon until it becomes crispy.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Rendering the bacon extracts the fat, which is essential for the sauce, and crisps the bacon, enhancing texture and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: While olive oil is not traditional, it can be used to start the cooking process if desired.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Crispy bacon with rendered fat, ready to be used in the pasta and as garnish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine cooked pasta with the egg and cheese mixture and rendered bacon to create the carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: Spaghetti has been cooked to al dente, and the egg and cheese mixture is ready. Bacon has been rendered and some fat retained in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghetti, egg and cheese mixture, rendered bacon, pan, tongs, pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Transfer the cooked spaghetti into the pan with rendered bacon using tongs. 2. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta. 3. Gently mix the pasta with the mixture, ensuring not to break the pasta. 4. Emulsify the sauce by stirring in bacon fat and pasta water as needed to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The heat from the pasta gently cooks the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. Emulsifying with pasta water helps achieve the desired texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it. Use thick pans that retain heat well, or consider placing the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat the mixture if needed.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A creamy, velvety carbonara sauce coats the spaghetti without scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine cooked pasta with the egg and cheese mixture and rendered bacon to create the carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: Spaghetti has been cooked to al dente, and the egg and cheese mixture is ready. Bacon has been rendered and some fat retained in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghetti, egg and cheese mixture, rendered bacon, pan, tongs, pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Transfer the cooked spaghetti into the pan with rendered bacon using tongs. 2. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta. 3. Gently mix the pasta with the mixture, ensuring not to break the pasta. 4. Emulsify the sauce by stirring in bacon fat and pasta water as needed to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The heat from the pasta gently cooks the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. Emulsifying with pasta water helps achieve the desired texture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it. Use thick pans that retain heat well, or consider placing the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat the mixture if needed.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A creamy, velvety carbonara sauce coats the spaghetti without scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve and Garnish
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Plate the spaghetti carbonara and garnish it.
subgoal_summaries.context: The carbonara sauce has been successfully made with a creamy texture, and the spaghetti is ready to be served.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Plate, tongs, grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, crispy bacon.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti carbonara onto a plate. 2. Sprinkle additional grated Parmigiano-Reggiano over the pasta. 3. Add crispy bacon on top for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Garnishing with extra cheese and bacon enhances the flavor and texture, providing added richness and crunch.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is plated neatly to enhance presentation. Adding extra bacon provides a satisfying crunch that complements the creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A plated serving of spaghetti carbonara garnished with cheese and crispy bacon, ready to be enjoyed.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The video demonstrates how to make an authentic spaghetti carbonara using traditional ingredients and techniques.
meta_summary.procedure: The process begins with preparing the pasta by twisting it into boiling water with a pinch of salt. While the pasta cooks, guanciale is sliced and rendered in a cold pan to extract the fat. Crushed garlic and cracked pepper are added for flavor. The egg is mixed with pecorino cheese. Once the guanciale is golden, the cooked pasta and some pasta water are added to the pan to stop frying and create an emulsion with the fat. The egg mixture is then combined with the pasta off the heat to form a creamy sauce. The dish is finished with extra pepper and pecorino cheese.
meta_summary.outcome: The result is a classic spaghetti carbonara with a creamy sauce made from emulsified fat and pasta water, rich with flavors of guanciale and pecorino cheese.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Black Peppercorns
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare black peppercorns for the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The procedure involves flavoring the dish with cracked pepper, added after rendering the guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Black peppercorns, pestle and mortar, sieve
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Place the black peppercorns in a pestle and mortar. 2. Crack the peppercorns. 3. Use a sieve to separate the milder outer skin from the hotter inner part.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The inner part of the peppercorn is hotter and more suitable for enhancing the flavor of the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: This step is often overlooked, but it is crucial for achieving a good, hot carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Prepared black pepper with the hotter inner part separated for use in the carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the egg mixture with the pasta to form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The cooked pasta and some pasta water are added to the pan with golden guanciale to create an emulsion with the fat. The egg is mixed with pecorino cheese separately.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Egg mixture (egg and pecorino cheese), cooked pasta, pasta water, pan with guanciale and emulsion.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Remove the pan from the heat. 2. Add the egg mixture to the pasta. 3. Stir quickly to combine and form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Mixing the egg mixture with the pasta off the heat prevents the eggs from scrambling and ensures a smooth, creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is off the heat before adding the egg mixture to avoid curdling.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg mixture and the emulsion.

subgoal_summaries.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the egg mixture with the pasta to form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The cooked pasta and some pasta water are added to the pan with golden guanciale to create an emulsion with the fat. The egg is mixed with pecorino cheese separately.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Egg mixture (egg and pecorino cheese), cooked pasta, pasta water, pan with guanciale and emulsion.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Remove the pan from the heat. 2. Add the egg mixture to the pasta. 3. Stir quickly to combine and form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Mixing the egg mixture with the pasta off the heat prevents the eggs from scrambling and ensures a smooth, creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is off the heat before adding the egg mixture to avoid curdling.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg mixture and the emulsion.

subgoal_summaries.title: Organize Ingredients for Cooking
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Organize the ingredients required for cooking spaghetti carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The goal is to make spaghetti carbonara with traditional ingredients and techniques, and understanding the specific ingredients is crucial for authenticity.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale, pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic egg, pasta, black pepper, optional garlic
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Using traditional ingredients like guanciale and pecorino romano ensures authenticity and the right flavor profile for the dish. The fat from guanciale is essential for the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure that the guanciale retains its fat, as it is crucial for the sauce. Pecorino romano is preferred over parmesan for a more authentic taste.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Having all the necessary ingredients organized and ready for cooking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the Pasta
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the pasta without it sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.context: The beginning of the process involves cooking the pasta, which is crucial for timing the rest of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Pasta, pot of boiling water, salt.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Grab the pasta by two hands. 2. Twist it into the boiling water. 3. Add a tiny amount of salt to the water. 4. Cook the pasta for eight minutes.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Twisting the pasta prevents it from sticking together. Salt is minimized because other ingredients are salty.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid over-salting the water because the cheese and guanciale are already salty.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is cooked and ready to be combined with other ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Render the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Render the guanciale and prepare the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.context: The guanciale needs to be prepared for rendering, and the egg mixture is to be combined later with the pasta to form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale, knife, cold pan, stove, garlic, eggs, pecorino cheese, bowl, whisk.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Remove the skin from the guanciale. 2. Slice the guanciale into 1 cm slices and chop into 0.5 cm chunks. 3. Place guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high. 4. Crack garlic and add to the pan. 5. Let the guanciale render and become golden. 6. Crack eggs into a bowl and add 20 grams of pecorino cheese. 7. Whisk the egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Starting with a cold pan helps render the fat from the guanciale slowly, enhancing the flavor. Preparing the egg mixture with pecorino cheese ensures it is ready to be combined with the pasta for a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is initially cold to properly render the guanciale fat. Be time-sensitive when preparing the egg mixture to avoid overcooking the guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Guanciale is rendered and golden, and the egg mixture is prepared with pecorino cheese for later use.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with rendered guanciale and create a creamy sauce using pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.context: The cooked pasta is ready, and the guanciale has been rendered to a golden color. The egg mixture is prepared separately for later use.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked pasta, pasta water, pan with rendered guanciale and fat.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Drag the cooked pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the rendered guanciale. 2. Use the pasta water to stop the frying process. 3. Ensure there is no frying sound to indicate the emulsion is forming. 4. Add more pasta water as needed to achieve a creamy consistency through emulsification.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The pasta water combines with the fat from the guanciale to create an emulsion, forming the base of the creamy sauce essential for carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Listen for the absence of frying sounds to confirm the emulsion is forming properly. Timing and technique are crucial to achieve the desired creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy emulsion of fat and pasta water, ready for the addition of the egg mixture to complete the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the egg mixture with the pasta to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta is coated in a creamy emulsion of fat and pasta water. The egg mixture, prepared separately, is ready to be added to the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Egg mixture, pan with pasta and emulsion.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Remove the pan from the heat. 2. Add the egg mixture to the pan with the pasta. 3. Stir quickly to combine and create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Removing the pan from the heat prevents the eggs from scrambling, allowing them to thicken into a creamy sauce instead.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is off the heat to avoid cooking the eggs too quickly. Stirring quickly helps incorporate the egg mixture evenly into the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg mixture, completing the carbonara dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve and Garnish
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Serve the finished spaghetti carbonara with garnishes.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta is coated in a creamy sauce made from the egg mixture, completing the carbonara dish.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghetti carbonara, extra cracked pepper, extra pecorino cheese.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Gather friends or family around the table. 2. Finish the carbonara with a sprinkle of extra pepper. 3. Add a final touch of pecorino cheese on top. 4. Serve the dish immediately.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Finishing the dish with extra pepper and pecorino enhances the flavors and presentation, highlighting the classic nature of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Emphasize the importance of using quality ingredients and proper techniques to achieve authentic flavors. Encourage enjoying the dish with loved ones.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The carbonara is served with additional pepper and pecorino, ready to be enjoyed by guests.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make an authentic carbonara pasta dish, emphasizing the correct ingredients and techniques to avoid common mistakes.
meta_summary.procedure: Start by boiling water and adding salt, then cook spaghettoni pasta. While pasta cooks, prepare the sauce by cooking guanciale (pork cheek) in olive oil. In a separate bowl, beat two egg yolks and mix with Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, and pepper. Once the pasta is cooked, mix it with the guanciale and its fat, then add the egg mixture to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Finish with additional cheese and pepper as garnish.
meta_summary.outcome: The final outcome is a creamy carbonara pasta dish with a rich flavor, achieved without adding cream, using traditional ingredients like guanciale, eggs, and cheese.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Black Peppercorns
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Mix the cooked pasta with the guanciale and its fat.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta has been boiled and cooked, and the guanciale has been cooked in olive oil.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghettoni pasta, cooked guanciale with its fat.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Combine the cooked pasta with the guanciale and its rendered fat in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The pasta needs to absorb the flavor from the guanciale and its fat, which forms the base of the carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is hot when mixing to help blend the flavors effectively.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is coated with the flavorful fat from the guanciale, ready to be mixed with the egg and cheese mixture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta is cooking, and the guanciale is being prepared in olive oil. The next step is to prepare the sauce ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Eggs, Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Separate the yolks from two eggs. 2. Beat the egg yolks in a bowl. 3. Add grated Parmesan cheese and Pecorino cheese to the yolks. 4. Add pepper to the mixture. 5. Stir the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The egg yolks form the base of the creamy sauce, which is traditional for carbonara. Adding Parmesan and Pecorino cheeses enhances the flavor, and pepper adds spice.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid adding cream to the sauce, as it is not traditional and is unnecessary for achieving the desired creamy texture.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A mixed egg and cheese base for the carbonara sauce, ready to be combined with the cooked pasta and guanciale.

subgoal_summaries.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Select and prepare the meat for the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The goal is to make an authentic carbonara, which requires using traditional ingredients like guanciale. Previous steps included starting to boil water for pasta.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale (pork cheek) or pancetta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut the guanciale into chunks.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Guanciale is traditionally used in carbonara for its tenderness and flavor, contributing to the authenticity of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If guanciale is unavailable, pancetta can be used as an alternative, though guanciale is preferred for authenticity.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The meat is cut into chunks, ready for cooking in the next steps.

subgoal_summaries.title: Organize Ingredients for Cooking
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Mix the cooked pasta with the guanciale and its fat.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta has been boiled and cooked, and the guanciale has been cooked in olive oil.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghettoni pasta, cooked guanciale with its rendered fat.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Combine the cooked pasta with the guanciale and the rendered fat in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Mixing the pasta with the guanciale and its fat ensures that the pasta absorbs the flavors of the guanciale, which is essential for an authentic carbonara taste.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is still hot when mixing to help it absorb the flavors effectively.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is now coated with the flavorful fat from the guanciale, ready for the next step of adding the egg mixture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the Pasta
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.context: The water is already boiling, which is necessary for adding the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Spaghettoni pasta, salt, boiling water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Add salt to the boiling water at a ratio of 10 grams per liter. 2. Add spaghettoni pasta to the boiling water. 3. Cook for about 10 minutes. 4. Stir the pasta slightly while it cooks.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Salt is added to season the pasta. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add oil to the water, as it is unnecessary and can prevent the sauce from adhering to the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is cooked al dente, ready to be mixed with other ingredients for the carbonara dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Render the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Render the meat for the carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The guanciale has been cut into chunks, ready for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale chunks, olive oil, pan.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Pour good olive oil into the pan. 2. Add the guanciale chunks into the pan with the olive oil.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Rendering the guanciale in olive oil is the start of the sauce and helps release the flavors and fat from the meat, which is essential for the carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure you use good quality olive oil for better flavor.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The guanciale is rendered in olive oil, creating the base for the carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta has been cooked al dente, and the guanciale has been rendered in olive oil, creating a flavorful base for the sauce. The egg and cheese mixture is ready to be added to the pasta and meat.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghettoni pasta, rendered guanciale with fat, egg and cheese mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Test the pasta for doneness and cook further if necessary. 2. Remove excess fat from the rendered guanciale if desired. 3. Mix the cooked pasta with the guanciale and its fat. 4. Turn off the heat and let the pasta cool slightly. 5. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta and stir to coat evenly.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Allowing the pasta to cool slightly before adding the egg mixture prevents the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid adding salt to the guanciale and pasta mixture as the guanciale is already salty. If the dish is too fatty, use paper towels to absorb excess fat before mixing with the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is combined with the guanciale and a creamy egg and cheese sauce, creating the classic carbonara dish without scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta has been cooked al dente, and the guanciale has been rendered in olive oil, creating a flavorful base for the sauce. The egg and cheese mixture is ready to be added to the pasta and meat.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked spaghettoni pasta, rendered guanciale with fat, egg and cheese mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Test the pasta for doneness and cook further if necessary. 2. Remove excess fat from the rendered guanciale if desired. 3. Mix the cooked pasta with the guanciale and its fat. 4. Turn off the heat and let the pasta cool slightly. 5. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta and stir to coat evenly.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Allowing the pasta to cool slightly before adding the egg mixture prevents the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid adding salt to the guanciale and pasta mixture as the guanciale is already salty. If the dish is too fatty, use paper towels to absorb excess fat before mixing with the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The pasta is combined with the guanciale and a creamy egg and cheese sauce, creating the classic carbonara dish without scrambling the eggs.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve and Garnish
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Serve and garnish the carbonara pasta.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta is combined with the guanciale and a creamy egg and cheese sauce, creating the classic carbonara dish without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Parmesan or Pecorino cheese, pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Garnish the pasta with Parmesan or Pecorino cheese, based on preference. 2. Add a touch of pepper as decoration.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Garnishing with cheese and pepper enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, emphasizing the authentic carbonara experience.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Choose between Parmesan or Pecorino cheese based on personal preference for the final garnish.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The carbonara pasta is garnished and ready to be served, presenting a creamy dish without the use of cream.

subtitles.text: Hey folks,

About a year ago,
a group of real-deal Italian chefs

savagely critiqued some of the biggest
Carbonara videos on the Internet.

And as you may remember,
my entry was not very well received.

Since then I've dreamt of
nothing but Redemption.

So today we're gonna take a crack at
two different versions of Carbonara,
a real-deal old-school Italian version,

and a more modern less traditional
version that's sure to piss em' off!
Let's get down to basics.
[Intro Music]
All right. So before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make "Carbonara"

which by definition, is made with
"Guanciale", a type of cured pork jowl.
It is very delicious but a little hard to find.

So if you can't find it, you can sub
with Pancetta if you're in a pinch.

I've got maybe a half-pound here that
I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks

and then set aside to make one of the essential
elements of any Carbonara dish: The Egg Slurry.

Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes 3 large eggs,
and 1 egg yolk for a little added richness.

And then it's time to finely grate and
measure out 4 ounces of cheese.

Truly traditional "Carbonara" uses
100% Pecorino Romano Cheese,

but is commonly balanced out
with Parmigiano-Reggiano.

If you want it a little less sharp and
a little more nutty, I'm going for a 50/50 ratio.
Into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.

We're then going to beat this whole affair
together with a fork until homogenous.

The only other thing you're gonna want to add is
a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.

We're not adding any salt yet
because "Guanciale" can vary in saltiness,
and we don't want to oversalt our dish.

Beat that together until well incorporated and
then it's time to head over to the Stovetop,
where we are introducing the "Guanciale" to a cold pan.
We're then gonna turn the heat to medium.

This is gonna cook the "Guanciale" more slowly
and allow more of its fat to render out
which in traditional "Carbonara" is a good thing.
Once it is fully cooked but not too crispy,

we're gonna kill the heat
and put our pasta in the hot tub.

The water is "Salato come il mare",
or as salty as the sea.

And we gotta keep it moving to
prevent it from sticking together.
And then a cool trick to determine pasta's doneness
is to take out a strand and eat it to see if it's done.
Don't throw it against the wall, you friggin' weirdo.

As you can see, our pork jowl has
almost entirely stopped bubbling.
That's exactly where we want it to be.
And as soon as the pasta is done,

we're dumping it directly into
the saute pan with the "Guanciale".

Once all the pasta is being added
we're gonna toss it around in the pan,

ensuring that it is evenly
covered in all that "Guanciale" fat.
And you wanna work quickly here.

Because the only thing that's going to
cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy
is the residual heat from the Pasta.

So waste no time getting the egg and cheese
mixture in there and then agitate rigorously!

This is going to help emulsify the sauce
and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling.

If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like,
you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a 1/4 cup.
But ideally, it should look just like this.

Now we're gonna taste for seasoning,
(Mine needs a little bit of salt).
Then you can optionally toss the pasta.

This is gonna help aerate it a little bit,
get that sauce super creamy!
And then, finally it's time to plate up!!

I like to use a carving fork to twirl the
pasta into a giant cylinder like this one
for presentation on a long narrow plate.

We are then of course going to
want to top this Hedonistic Helix

with the remaining "Guanciale"
from the bottom of the pan
along with any remnants of that creamy sauce!
And there you have it folks!
I'm going to say it one last time:

"Carbonara",
in its purest most authentic and traditional form.

Unless of course I got something
wrong, in which case I'm in trouble.

But at this point I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave
the room, because it's time to make carbonara.

This starts very much the same way
with Parmesan and Romano cheese

grated into a bowl along with
3 eggs and 1 egg yolk,

beaten together with a few healthy
twists of freshly ground black pepper.

Now when most Americans make
Carbonara, they reach for the bacon.

If you can't find "Guanciale" or "Pancetta"
and you got to use bacon,
just go for the thick-cut stuff.

And likewise we're gonna slice about
1/2 a pound of it into big ol' chunks.

Then likewise, we're gonna start
these guys off in a cold pan,

because we want to render out as much fat
as possible, but not for the same reason.
You'll also notice that I'm using a nonstick pan.

And that's because in the stainless, bacon can leave
a lot of fond on the bottom of the pot.

Which for once we don't want, as it might
make our final pasta look kind of dirty.

Once the bacon is fully cooked and the fat
rendered out, we are going to strain it.

Because this version of Carbonara
is going to have a much lighter sauce.

We're just going to strain off all but
about 2 tbsp worth of bacon fat,
which we're gonna leave in the pan.

And then we're gonna return it over medium-low heat to
add the most egregious ingredient of all: garlic.

This is considered sacrilege
in the world of "Carbonara",

but I think it tastes really
really good, and so will you.

We're just sautéing for 1 minute
until fragrant before killing the heat.

Next up, I see far too many people just
dump pasta out of the box in the water
which inevitably leads to disaster.

Give this a shot, where you dump
the pasta into the palm of your hand

and then pull it out using
your hand, like a real gentleman.

And as you can see, this time
I'm going with Bucatini.

Next up, just like last time we're adding
the pasta directly to the pan,

but this time we're gonna add about
1/3 of a cup of starchy pasta water
which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce.

Then we are adding the egg
and cheese mixture to the party.

And if you find yourself in a pickle like this where
your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie!
Just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot.

Just make sure that you keep it moving
because there's a lot of residual heat in here

and we don't want to end up with
pasta and scrambled eggs.

So just wildly agitate that around
and then it's time to taste for seasoning!

Add salt and pepper as necessary
and assess your sauce's thickness.

If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan.

Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously.
And now it's time to plate up!!
And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara

is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat.

It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara".

And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely.

Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself,

I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks!

Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.

your hand, like a real gentleman.

And as you can see, this time
I'm going with Bucatini.

Next up, just like last time we're adding
the pasta directly to the pan,

but this time we're gonna add about
1/3 of a cup of starchy pasta water
which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce.

Then we are adding the egg
and cheese mixture to the party.

And if you find yourself in a pickle like this where
your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie!
Just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot.

Just make sure that you keep it moving
because there's a lot of residual heat in here

and we don't want to end up with
pasta and scrambled eggs.

So just wildly agitate that around
and then it's time to taste for seasoning!

Add salt and pepper as necessary
and assess your sauce's thickness.

If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan.

Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously.
And now it's time to plate up!!
And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara

is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat.

It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara".

And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely.

Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself,

I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks!

Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.

common_steps.title: Introduction (custom)
common_steps.text:
Hey folks, About a year ago,
a group of real-deal Italian chefs savagely critiqued some of the biggest
Carbonara videos on the Internet. And as you may remember,
my entry was not very well received. Since then I've dreamt of
nothing but Redemption. So today we're gonna take a crack at
two different versions of Carbonara, a real-deal old-school Italian version, and a more modern less traditional
version that's sure to piss em' off! Let's get down to basics.
common_steps.explanation: This segment introduces the video and sets the context for what will be covered, which is a redemption attempt on making Carbonara.

common_steps.title: Intro Music (custom)
common_steps.text: [Intro Music]
common_steps.explanation: This segment consists solely of the intro music, marking a transition in the video.

common_steps.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
common_steps.text:
All right. So before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make "Carbonara" which by definition, is made with
"Guanciale", a type of cured pork jowl. It is very delicious but a little hard to find. So if you can't find it, you can sub
with Pancetta if you're in a pinch. I've got maybe a half-pound here that
I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks
common_steps.explanation: This segment is about selecting and preparing the meat, specifically guanciale or pancetta, which aligns with the subgoal of choosing and cutting the meat.

common_steps.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
common_steps.text:
I've got maybe a half-pound here that
I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks and then set aside to make one of the essential
elements of any Carbonara dish: The Egg Slurry. Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes 3 large eggs,
and 1 egg yolk for a little added richness. And then it's time to finely grate and
measure out 4 ounces of cheese. Truly traditional "Carbonara" uses
100% Pecorino Romano Cheese, but is commonly balanced out
with Parmigiano-Reggiano. If you want it a little less sharp and
a little more nutty, I'm going for a 50/50 ratio. Into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs. We're then going to beat this whole affair
together with a fork until homogenous. The only other thing you're gonna want to add is
a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper. We're not adding any salt yet
because "Guanciale" can vary in saltiness,
common_steps.explanation: This segment covers the grating of cheese and preparation of the egg mixture, which aligns with the subgoal of preparing the cheese and eggs for the sauce.

common_steps.title: Render the Meat
common_steps.text:
and we don't want to oversalt our dish. Beat that together until well incorporated and
then it's time to head over to the Stovetop, where we are introducing the "Guanciale" to a cold pan. We're then gonna turn the heat to medium. This is gonna cook the "Guanciale" more slowly
and allow more of its fat to render out which in traditional "Carbonara" is a good thing. Once it is fully cooked but not too crispy, we're gonna kill the heat
and put our pasta in the hot tub.
common_steps.explanation: This segment describes the process of cooking the guanciale to render its fat, which matches the subgoal of rendering the meat.

common_steps.title: Cook the Pasta
common_steps.text:
The water is "Salato come il mare",
or as salty as the sea. And we gotta keep it moving to
prevent it from sticking together. And then a cool trick to determine pasta's doneness is to take out a strand and eat it to see if it's done. Don't throw it against the wall, you friggin' weirdo.
common_steps.explanation: This segment focuses on cooking the pasta until al dente, which is the primary task in the subgoal of cooking the pasta.

common_steps.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
common_steps.text:
As you can see, our pork jowl has
almost entirely stopped bubbling. That's exactly where we want it to be. And as soon as the pasta is done, we're dumping it directly into
the saute pan with the "Guanciale". Once all the pasta is being added
we're gonna toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly
covered in all that "Guanciale" fat. And you wanna work quickly here. Because the only thing that's going to
cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the Pasta. So waste no time getting the egg and cheese
mixture in there and then agitate rigorously! This is going to help emulsify the sauce
and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling. If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like,
you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a 1/4 cup. But ideally, it should look just like this.
common_steps.explanation: This segment involves combining the cooked pasta with the guanciale and the egg and cheese mixture, which aligns with the subgoal of combining pasta with meat and sauce ingredients.

common_steps.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
common_steps.text:
Now we're gonna taste for seasoning,
(Mine needs a little bit of salt). Then you can optionally toss the pasta. This is gonna help aerate it a little bit,
get that sauce super creamy!
common_steps.explanation: This segment is about tasting the dish and adjusting the seasoning, which directly corresponds to the subgoal of tasting and adjusting seasoning.

common_steps.title: Serve and Garnish
common_steps.text:
And then, finally it's time to plate up!! I like to use a carving fork to twirl the
pasta into a giant cylinder like this one for presentation on a long narrow plate. We are then of course going to
want to top this Hedonistic Helix with the remaining "Guanciale"
from the bottom of the pan along with any remnants of that creamy sauce! And there you have it folks! I'm going to say it one last time: "Carbonara",
in its purest most authentic and traditional form.
common_steps.explanation: This segment covers the serving and garnishing of the dish, which aligns with the subgoal of serving and garnishing the carbonara.

common_steps.title: Transition to Modern Version (custom)
common_steps.text:
Unless of course I got something
wrong, in which case I'm in trouble. But at this point I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave
the room, because it's time to make carbonara.
common_steps.explanation: This segment transitions from the traditional Carbonara to the modern version, marking a shift in focus.

common_steps.title: Prepare Modern Carbonara (custom)
common_steps.text:
This starts very much the same way
with Parmesan and Romano cheese grated into a bowl along with
3 eggs and 1 egg yolk, beaten together with a few healthy
twists of freshly ground black pepper. Now when most Americans make
Carbonara, they reach for the bacon. If you can't find "Guanciale" or "Pancetta"
and you got to use bacon, just go for the thick-cut stuff. And likewise we're gonna slice about
1/2 a pound of it into big ol' chunks. Then likewise, we're gonna start
these guys off in a cold pan, because we want to render out as much fat
as possible, but not for the same reason. You'll also notice that I'm using a nonstick pan. And that's because in the stainless, bacon can leave
a lot of fond on the bottom of the pot. Which for once we don't want, as it might
make our final pasta look kind of dirty. Once the bacon is fully cooked and the fat
rendered out, we are going to strain it. Because this version of Carbonara
is going to have a much lighter sauce. We're just going to strain off all but
about 2 tbsp worth of bacon fat, which we're gonna leave in the pan. And then we're gonna return it over medium-low heat to
add the most egregious ingredient of all: garlic. This is considered sacrilege
in the world of "Carbonara", but I think it tastes really
really good, and so will you. We're just sautéeing for 1 minute
until fragrant before killing the heat.
common_steps.explanation: This segment explains the preparation of the modern version of Carbonara, including the use of bacon and garlic, which deviates from traditional methods.

common_steps.title: Cook and Finish Modern Carbonara (custom)
common_steps.text:
Next up, I see far too many people just
dump pasta out of the box in the water which inevitably leads to disaster. Give this a shot, where you dump
the pasta into the palm of your hand and then pull it out using
your hand, like a real gentleman. And as you can see, this time
I'm going with Bucatini. Next up, just like last time we're adding
the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about
1/3 of a cup of starchy pasta water which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce. Then we are adding the egg
and cheese mixture to the party. And if you find yourself in a pickle like this where
your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie! Just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot. Just make sure that you keep it moving
because there's a lot of residual heat in here and we don't want to end up with
pasta and scrambled eggs. So just wildly agitate that around
and then it's time to taste for seasoning! Add salt and pepper as necessary
and assess your sauce's thickness. If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it
with a little bit of finely-grated Parmesan. Just add maybe another 1/4 oz
or so and mix rigorously. And now it's time to plate up!! And one thing you'll notice about this Carbonara is that the sauce is much lighter
because it has a lot less fat. It also stays creamier longer and
won't congeal as quickly as "Carbonara". And the Bucatini, while a little bit difficult to
get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely.
common_steps.explanation: This segment covers the cooking and finishing steps for the modern Carbonara, including pasta cooking, sauce mixing, and plating.

common_steps.title: Conclusion (custom)
common_steps.text:
Whichever version of Carbonara
you decide to make for yourself, I hope this has shown you how easy it can be,
so long as you follow a few simple tricks! Now go out there, get some pasta,
and start rolling your R's.
common_steps.explanation: This segment concludes the video, summarizing the process and encouraging viewers to try making Carbonara themselves.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The video aims to demonstrate how to make two versions of Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.
meta_summary.procedure: The process begins with preparing the essential ingredients: guanciale or pancetta, eggs, and cheese. For the traditional version, guanciale is cooked slowly in a cold pan to render the fat, while pasta is cooked in salty water. The egg and cheese mixture is combined with the hot pasta and guanciale fat to create a creamy sauce. For the modern version, bacon is cooked and strained, garlic is added, and a lighter sauce is made by adding pasta water before combining with the egg and cheese mixture. Both versions are plated with the pasta twirled for presentation.
meta_summary.outcome: The outcome is two plated versions of Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamy longer. Both demonstrate different techniques and ingredients for making Carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Black Peppercorns
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Begin cooking the guanciale for the traditional Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The essential ingredients have been prepared, including guanciale, which is used for the traditional version of Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale, cold pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Place the guanciale in a cold pan and slowly heat it to render the fat.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooking the guanciale in a cold pan allows the fat to render slowly, which is crucial for creating a rich, creamy sauce for the Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is low to prevent burning and to allow maximum fat rendering.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The guanciale is cooked, and its fat is rendered, providing a base for the sauce in the traditional Carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Grate Cheese and Prepare Eggs
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Prepare the cheese and egg mixture for the Carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The overall procedure involves making Carbonara, where the cheese and egg mixture forms the base of the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.materials: 3 large eggs, 1 egg yolk, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, black pepper.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Cut cheese into sizable chunks. 2. Crack 3 large eggs and add 1 egg yolk into a medium bowl. 3. Finely grate 4 ounces of cheese, choosing a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano. 4. Combine the beaten eggs with the grated cheese. 5. Beat the mixture with a fork until homogenous. 6. Add freshly ground black pepper to taste.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The egg and cheese mixture is a crucial part of the Carbonara sauce, providing richness and creaminess. Black pepper adds flavor, and salt is omitted due to the variable saltiness of guanciale.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a 50/50 ratio of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano for a balanced flavor profile.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A homogenous mixture of eggs, cheese, and pepper, ready to be combined with pasta and guanciale fat to create the Carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Select and Prepare the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Select and prepare the meat for Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: To make Carbonara, the initial step involves selecting the appropriate cured meat, which is either guanciale for the traditional version or pancetta if guanciale is unavailable.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale or pancetta, cutting board, knife.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Obtain about a half-pound of guanciale. 2. Cut the guanciale into relatively sizable chunks.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Guanciale is the traditional meat used in Carbonara, providing authentic flavor, but pancetta can be substituted if guanciale is hard to find.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Guanciale can be difficult to find, so pancetta is a suitable alternative in a pinch.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Prepared chunks of guanciale or pancetta ready for cooking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Organize Ingredients for Cooking
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Begin cooking the guanciale for the traditional Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.context: The guanciale has been prepared and is ready to be cooked to render the fat.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale, cold pan, stove
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Place the guanciale in a cold pan. 2. Set the stove to low heat. 3. Cook slowly until the fat is rendered and the guanciale is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooking the guanciale slowly in a cold pan allows the fat to render out gradually, which is essential for achieving the right texture and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan starts cold to maximize fat rendering and prevent burning.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The guanciale becomes crispy, and the rendered fat is used for the Carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the Pasta
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Cook the pasta until it is al dente.
subgoal_summaries.context: The pasta needs to be cooked in salty water as part of preparing the traditional and modern Carbonara versions.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Pasta, salty water
subgoal_summaries.instructions:
1. Ensure the water is as salty as the sea.
2. Keep the pasta moving in the water to prevent sticking.
3. Test the pasta's doneness by tasting a strand.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Salty water seasons the pasta, and constant movement prevents sticking. Tasting ensures the pasta is cooked to the desired texture (al dente).
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not throw the pasta against the wall to test doneness; this is a humorous reference.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Pasta cooked to al dente, ready to be combined with other ingredients.

subgoal_summaries.title: Render the Meat
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Render the guanciale to extract its fat.
subgoal_summaries.context: Prepared chunks of guanciale from the previous step are ready for cooking.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Guanciale, cold pan, stovetop.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Place the guanciale into a cold pan. 2. Turn the heat to medium. 3. Cook until the guanciale is fully cooked but not too crispy. 4. Turn off the heat.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Cooking the guanciale slowly in a cold pan allows more fat to render out, which is essential for the traditional Carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Avoid making the guanciale too crispy to maintain the right texture and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Guanciale is cooked with rendered fat, ready to be combined with pasta for the Carbonara sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta with Meat and Sauce Ingredients
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Combine the cooked pasta with guanciale and the egg and cheese mixture to create the Carbonara sauce.
subgoal_summaries.context: The guanciale has been rendered and is ready in the sauté pan. The pasta is cooked al dente and ready to be combined with the other ingredients. The egg and cheese mixture is prepared for making the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Cooked pasta, rendered guanciale in pan, egg and cheese mixture, optional pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.instructions:
1. Dump the cooked pasta directly into the sauté pan with the guanciale.
2. Toss the pasta around to coat it evenly in guanciale fat.
3. Quickly add the egg and cheese mixture to the pan.
4. Agitate the mixture vigorously to emulsify the sauce.
5. If needed, add a little pasta water to achieve desired smoothness.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy. Agitation helps emulsify the sauce and prevent curdling.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Work quickly to ensure the pasta's residual heat properly cooks the egg mixture. If the sauce isn't smooth, add a small amount of pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: A smooth, creamy Carbonara sauce that coats the pasta evenly.

subgoal_summaries.title: Taste and Adjust Seasoning
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Taste and adjust the seasoning of the Carbonara dish.
subgoal_summaries.context: The Carbonara sauce has been combined with the pasta and is ready for final adjustments before serving.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Prepared Carbonara pasta dish, salt (if needed).
subgoal_summaries.instructions:
1. Taste the Carbonara dish to evaluate the seasoning.
2. Add salt if necessary.
3. Optionally toss the pasta to aerate and enhance creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Tasting the dish ensures the seasoning is balanced. Aerating the pasta by tossing can make the sauce creamier.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Tossing the pasta can help improve the texture and creaminess of the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The Carbonara dish is properly seasoned and ready to be served with an enhanced creamy texture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Serve and Garnish
subgoal_summaries.subgoal: Serve and garnish the Carbonara dish for presentation.
subgoal_summaries.context: The Carbonara dish has been tasted and adjusted for seasoning, and is ready to be plated.
subgoal_summaries.materials: Carving fork, long narrow plate, remaining guanciale, creamy sauce remnants.
subgoal_summaries.instructions:
1. Use a carving fork to twirl the pasta into a cylinder shape.
2. Place the pasta on a long narrow plate.
3. Top with remaining guanciale and sauce remnants.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Twisting the pasta into a cylinder shape enhances presentation. Topping with guanciale and sauce adds flavor and visual appeal.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Using a carving fork helps achieve a neat pasta cylinder for presentation.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: The Carbonara dish is attractively plated and garnished, ready to serve in an appealing presentation.
